translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽The Chapter with Citaka and the Worshipper
The Elder Gosīsanikkhepaka’s Birth Story
“Having left the monastery gate,
I spread out a cow’s head.
I experience my own deeds,

analyzed: pubba kammassa idam  ājāniyā vāta javā
translated: this is the fruit of my past deeds.🔽The swift-footed horses,
the Sindhu horses, the swift-moving ones,
I experience all this,
this is the fruit of the cow’s head.
Oh, the deed, the supreme deed,
the good field was well-prepared by me.
For the deed done to the Saṅgha,
I do not value any other path.
For ninety-four eons,
the head I spread out,
I do not know of any bad destination,
this is the fruit of the spreading out.
In the fifty-fifth eon,
named Suppatiṭṭhita,
there was one of great splendor,
a powerful wheel-turning monarch.
The four analytical knowledges,
the Buddha’s instruction has been fulfilled.”🔽Thus did the Elder Gosīsanikkhepaka recite these verses.

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā gosīsanikkhepako thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.🔽Gosīsanikkhepakattherassāpadānaṁ pañcamaṁ.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmā gosīsanikkhepakaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati 🔽gosīsanikkhepaka therassa apadānam pañcama
translated: The Elder Gosīsanikkhepaka’s Birth Story is the fifth.
